cells.content: Fonds de Protection / Beschermings Fonds / Protection Fund [7]
Saving limit was EUR 51,129 in the period: April 15, 1998 - December 31, 2010

Previously (since 2002), the insured amount was 90?% of deposits up to EUR 25,000; in 2008 it was increased to 100% of deposits up to EUR 50,000. Effective 2011, the limit was increased to EUR 100,000. Credit unions covered since 2006.[8]
Ordinary deposit guarantee scheme applies after September 30, 2010, covers up to DKK750,000
Garantifonden for indskydere og investorer, The Guarantee Fund for Depositors and Investors
http://www.indskydergarantifonden.dk For the two year period from October 5, 2008 to September 30, 2010 an unlimited governmental guarantee for deposits has been added.[9][10]
Increased from EUR 25,000 to EUR 50,000 on October 8, 2008[11] and to EUR 100,000 on January 1, 2011.[12]

Unlimited state guarantee? Following the Irish legislative change to unlimited state guarantee, and the German announcement of unlimited support, the French President declared on 13 October 2008 that "The government will not let any French bank fail",[14] in a speech that was posted on the official website www.gouvernement.fr. This political commitment has so far held (rescue of the Franco-Belgian bank DEXIA)

Bundesverband deutscher Banken BdB (for private banks) Bundesverband ?ffentlicher Banken Deutschlands V?B (for public sector banks) Bundesverband der Deutschen Volksbanken und Raiffeisenbanken BVR (for co-operative banks) Deutscher Sparkassen- und Giroverband DSGV (Savings banks)

The 4 banking associations (see previous column) run voluntary additional guarantee schemes, which go beyond the European minimum of EUR 100,000. For instance for BdB member banks, "The protection ceiling for each creditor is 30% of the liable capital of the Bank..."[15] An unlimited state guarantee was announced in October 2008 (and extended in July 2009). The legal details are nevertheless unclear.[16] "It is a political declaration" said Torsten Albig.[17]
Central Bank and Financial Services Authority of Ireland
Amount raised to unlimited in September 2008
Fondo Interbancario di Tutela dei Depositi (FITD)
Before October 7, 2008 coverage was 100% of first EUR 20,000, 90% of next EUR 20,000 (hence a compensation of up to EUR 38,000). The raised amount is valid until December 31, 2010.[20]
Amount raised from EUR 50,000 on 30 December 2010
Amount raised from EUR 25,000 to EUR 100,000 in November 2008.[22]
Slovene: Banka Slovenije, the central bank of the Republic of Slovenia
[24] The Bank of Slovenia joined the Eurosystem in 2007, when the euro replaced the tolar.
Amount raised from 35,000 to GBP 50,000 effective October 7, 2008. Before October 1, 2007 coverage was 100% of the first GBP 2,000 and 90% between 2,000 and GBP 35,000.[27]
From October 2008 to December 2010, amount was SEK 500,000.[26]
Ordinary deposit guarantee scheme applies after September 30, 2010, covers up to DKK750,000
Fonds de Protection / Beschermings Fonds / Protection Fund [7]
Garantifonden for indskydere og investorer, The Guarantee Fund for Depositors and Investors

Bundesverband deutscher Banken BdB (for private banks) Bundesverband ?ffentlicher Banken Deutschlands V?B (for public sector banks) Bundesverband der Deutschen Volksbanken und Raiffeisenbanken BVR (for co-operative banks) Deutscher Sparkassen- und Giroverband DSGV (Savings banks)
Central Bank and Financial Services Authority of Ireland
Fondo Interbancario di Tutela dei Depositi (FITD)
Slovene: Banka Slovenije, the central bank of the Republic of Slovenia
Saving limit was EUR 51,129 in the period: April 15, 1998 - December 31, 2010

Previously (since 2002), the insured amount was 90?% of deposits up to EUR 25,000; in 2008 it was increased to 100% of deposits up to EUR 50,000. Effective 2011, the limit was increased to EUR 100,000. Credit unions covered since 2006.[8]
http://www.indskydergarantifonden.dk For the two year period from October 5, 2008 to September 30, 2010 an unlimited governmental guarantee for deposits has been added.[9][10]
Increased from EUR 25,000 to EUR 50,000 on October 8, 2008[11] and to EUR 100,000 on January 1, 2011.[12]

Unlimited state guarantee? Following the Irish legislative change to unlimited state guarantee, and the German announcement of unlimited support, the French President declared on 13 October 2008 that "The government will not let any French bank fail",[14] in a speech that was posted on the official website www.gouvernement.fr. This political commitment has so far held (rescue of the Franco-Belgian bank DEXIA)

The 4 banking associations (see previous column) run voluntary additional guarantee schemes, which go beyond the European minimum of EUR 100,000. For instance for BdB member banks, "The protection ceiling for each creditor is 30% of the liable capital of the Bank..."[15] An unlimited state guarantee was announced in October 2008 (and extended in July 2009). The legal details are nevertheless unclear.[16] "It is a political declaration" said Torsten Albig.[17]
Amount raised to unlimited in September 2008
Before October 7, 2008 coverage was 100% of first EUR 20,000, 90% of next EUR 20,000 (hence a compensation of up to EUR 38,000). The raised amount is valid until December 31, 2010.[20]
Amount raised from EUR 50,000 on 30 December 2010
Amount raised from EUR 25,000 to EUR 100,000 in November 2008.[22]
[24] The Bank of Slovenia joined the Eurosystem in 2007, when the euro replaced the tolar.
From October 2008 to December 2010, amount was SEK 500,000.[26]
Amount raised from 35,000 to GBP 50,000 effective October 7, 2008. Before October 1, 2007 coverage was 100% of the first GBP 2,000 and 90% between 2,000 and GBP 35,000.[27]
